location.description: Location of the event (physical or online).

imageUrl.description: URL of the image associated with the event.

Testimonial.title: Testimonial
Testimonial.description: Represents a testimonial from a member.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Testimonial entity.

authorName.description: Name of the author of the testimonial.

content.description: The text content of the testimonial.

TeamMember.title: TeamMember
TeamMember.description: Represents a member of the Muslimahs Club team.

id.description: Unique identifier for the TeamMember entity.

title.description: Title or role of the team member.

bio.description: Short biography of the team member.

imageUrl.description: URL of the team member's image.

ForumPost.title: ForumPost
ForumPost.description: Represents a question posted in the open forum.

id.description: Unique identifier for the ForumPost entity.

authorName.description: Name of the user who posted the question.

answer.description: Admin's answer to the question.  Can be null if unanswered.

timestamp.description: Timestamp of when the question was posted.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to support the Muslimahs Club application, focusing on ease of management for events, testimonials, team members, and forum answers via a backend admin page.  The primary goal is to create a structure that is secure, scalable, and facilitates simple security rules, particularly around who can create, read, update, and delete each type of entity.

**Authorization Independence:**  All data is stored in root-level collections, enabling straightforward security rules based on admin role.  No `get()` calls are required in the rules, making them more efficient and easier to debug.

**Structural Segregation:**  Each content type (events, testimonials, team members, forum posts) is stored in its own dedicated collection. This segregation ensures a homogeneous security posture for each content type, simplifying security rule definition.

**QAPs (Rules are not Filters):** The structure inherently supports secure `list` operations.  Since admin access is managed at the collection level, listing all documents within a collection is secured by verifying the request originates from an admin.

Given the requirement for an admin page to manage content, a simple role-based access control (RBAC) model is implemented. The presence of a document in the `/roles_admin/{uid}` collection signifies that the user is an administrator.
